title: Darwinism
description:
Theory of evolution through natural selection
Example: Finches

title: Lamarckism
description:
Theory of acquired traits being inherited
Example: Giraffe Neck

title: Natural Selection
description:
Survival and reproduction of the fittest organisms
Example: Peppered Moth

title: Survival of the Fittest
description:
Best-adapted individuals survive and reproduce
Example: Cheetah Speed

title: Speciation
description:
Formation of new species through evolution
Example: Galápagos Finches

title: Adaptive Radiation
description:
Rapid diversification of species into different niches
Example: Darwin’s Finches

title: Convergent Evolution
description:
Unrelated species evolving similar traits
Example: Shark & Dolphin

title: Divergent Evolution
description:
Related species evolving different traits
Example: Wolf & Dog

title: Co-evolution
description:
Mutual evolutionary influence between species
Example: Bees & Flowers

title: Punctuated Equilibrium
description:
Evolution occurring in rapid bursts
Example: Trilobites

title: Gradualism
description:
Gradual evolutionary changes over time
Example: Horse Evolution

title: Vestigial Structures
description:
Remnants of once-functional structures
Example: Human Appendix

title: Homologous Structures
description:
Similar structures from common ancestry
Example: Bat Wing & Human Arm

title: Analogous Structures
description:
Similar function but different evolutionary origins
Example: Bird & Insect Wing

title: Genetic Drift
description:
Random changes in allele frequencies
Example: Isolated Island Populations

title: Founder Effect
description:
Genetic drift from a small founding population
Example: Small Island Colonization

title: Bottleneck Effect
description:
Sharp reduction in population size and genetic diversity
Example: Genetic Bottleneck in Cheetahs

title: Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium
description:
Principle of genetic equilibrium
Example: Stable Population Genetics

title: Microevolution
description:
Small evolutionary changes within a population
Example: Antibiotic Resistance

title: Macroevolution
description:
Large evolutionary changes over long periods
Example: Dinosaur Evolution

title: Extinction
description:
Complete disappearance of a species
Example: Dodo

title: Mass Extinction
description:
Widespread extinction events
Example: Cretaceous-Paleogene Event

title: Fossil
description:
Preserved remains of ancient organisms
Example: Amber Insect

title: Transitional Fossil
description:
Fossils showing intermediary evolutionary traits
Example: Archaeopteryx

title: Living Fossil
description:
Modern species resembling ancient forms
Example: Coelacanth

title: Trace Fossil
description:
Fossilized biological activity traces
Example: Dinosaur Tracks

title: Paleontology
description:
Study of fossils and evolutionary history
Example: Fossilized Trilobites

title: Radiometric Dating
description:
Dating fossils using radioactive decay
Example: Carbon-14 Dating

title: Relative Dating
description:
Estimating fossil age using rock layers
Example: Stratigraphy

title: Index Fossil
description:
Fossils used for dating rock layers
Example: Ammonites

title: Permineralization
description:
Minerals replacing organic material in fossils
Example: Petrified Wood

title: Taphonomy
description:
Study of fossilization processes
Example: Fossilization Process

title: Cambrian Explosion
description:
Explosion of diverse life forms in Cambrian period
Example: Burgess Shale

title: Extinct Megafauna
description:
Large extinct prehistoric animals
Example: Woolly Mammoth

title: Pleistocene Extinction
description:
Mass extinction of Ice Age megafauna
Example: Saber-Toothed Cat

title: Fossil Record
description:
Collection of all known fossils
Example: Dinosaur Skeletons

title: Social Behavior
description:
Interactions influencing survival and reproduction
Example: Chimpanzee Groups

title: Altruism
description:
Sacrificing for the benefit of others
Example: Vampire Bat Sharing

title: Kin Selection
description:
Helping relatives survive to pass on genes
Example: Honeybee Kin Selection

title: Cooperative Hunting
description:
Hunting strategy involving teamwork
Example: Wolves

title: Dominance Hierarchy
description:
Social ranking influencing resource access
Example: Gorilla Troops

title: Territoriality
description:
Defending a specific area
Example: Wolf Packs

title: Aggressive Mimicry
description:
Mimicry used by predators to catch prey
Example: Anglerfish Lure

title: Eusociality
description:
Highest level of social organization
Example: Ant Colonies

title: Mimicry
description:
Resembling another species for survival
Example: Viceroy Butterfly

title: Communication
description:
Exchange of information between organisms
Example: Dolphin Clicks

title: Migration
description:
Seasonal movement of animals
Example: Wildebeest Journey

title: Hibernation
description:
Metabolic slowdown to survive harsh conditions
Example: Bear Winter Sleep

title: Aestivation
description:
Dormancy in hot, dry conditions
Example: Desert Snail

title: Diapause
description:
Developmental pause due to environmental stress
Example: Insect Eggs

title: Philopatry
description:
Returning to birthplace for breeding
Example: Salmon Spawning

title: Nomadism
description:
Moving without a fixed home range
Example: Caribou Herds

title: Torpor
description:
Short-term energy-saving state
Example: Bats

title: Site Fidelity
description:
Returning to the same location repeatedly
Example: Bird Migration

title: Imprinting
description:
Early-life learning of strong associations
Example: Ducklings

title: Territorial Dispute
description:
Conflict over territorial ownership
Example: Songbirds

title: Foraging Behavior
description:
Strategies for food collection
Example: Squirrel Caching

title: Parental Investment
description:
Energy and resources devoted to offspring
Example: Penguin Care

title: Sexual Selection
description:
Traits increasing reproductive success
Example: Peacock Feathers

title: Mate Guarding
description:
Preventing rivals from mating
Example: Dragonflies

title: Lek Behavior
description:
Males gathering for mating displays
Example: Sage Grouse

title: Courtship Display
description:
Ritualized behaviors to attract mates
Example: Bird Dance

title: Polygamy
description:
One individual having multiple mates
Example: Lions

title: Monogamy
description:
Pairing with only one mate
Example: Swans

title: Infanticide
description:
Killing offspring to increase mating chances
Example: Lions

title: Cooperative Breeding
description:
Helping non-kin raise young
Example: Meerkats

title: Brood Parasitism
description:
Laying eggs in other species' nests
Example: Cuckoo Bird

title: Group Living
description:
Living in organized social groups
Example: Baboons

title: Predator-Prey Interaction
description:
Interaction between predator and prey
Example: Wolves & Deer

title: Alarm Calls
description:
Vocal warnings of predators
Example: Prairie Dogs

title: Camouflage
description:
Blending into the environment
Example: Chameleons

title: Crypsis
description:
Avoiding detection using camouflage
Example: Stick Insects

title: Aposematism
description:
Bright colors warning of toxicity
Example: Poison Dart Frog

title: Batesian Mimicry
description:
Harmless species mimicking harmful ones
Example: Hoverfly

title: Müllerian Mimicry
description:
Harmful species mimicking each other
Example: Monarch & Viceroy Butterflies

title: Habitat Selection
description:
Choosing habitats based on resources
Example: Nesting Birds

title: Niche Partitioning
description:
Species dividing resources to avoid competition
Example: Anole Lizards

title: Mutualism
description:
Both species benefit from interaction
Example: Clownfish & Anemone

title: Commensalism
description:
One species benefits, the other is unaffected
Example: Barnacles & Whales

title: Parasitism
description:
One species benefits at another’s expense
Example: Ticks

title: Intraspecific Competition
description:
Competition within a species
Example: Deer Fighting

title: Interspecific Competition
description:
Competition between different species
Example: Wolves & Coyotes

title: Territorial Marking
description:
Using signals to mark territory
Example: Tiger Scratches

title: Flocking Behavior
description:
Coordinated group movement
Example: Starlings

title: Swarming
description:
Large groups moving together
Example: Locusts

title: Schooling
description:
Synchronized fish movement
Example: Sardines

title: Pack Behavior
description:
Cooperative group hunting and living
Example: Wolves

title: Dominance Display
description:
Asserting social status
Example: Gorilla Chest Beating

title: Submissive Behavior
description:
Signals of surrender
Example: Dog Rolling Over

title: Chemical Communication
description:
Using pheromones for communication
Example: Ant Trails

title: Visual Communication
description:
Using body movements or colors
Example: Fireflies

title: Acoustic Communication
description:
Using sound for communication
Example: Dolphin Clicks

title: Tactile Communication
description:
Using touch for interaction
Example: Grooming in Monkeys

title: Migration Corridor
description:
Consistently used migration route
Example: Serengeti Pathway

title: Flyway
description:
Specific bird migration path
Example: Arctic Tern Route

title: Partial Migration
description:
Only part of a population migrates
Example: American Robins

title: Altitudinal Migration
description:
Migration between different elevations
Example: Mountain Goats

title: Reverse Migration
description:
Unexpected migration direction
Example: Monarch Butterflies

title: Nomadic Migration
description:
Unpredictable movement following resources
Example: Wildebeests

title: Irruptive Migration
description:
Irregular migration due to resource changes
Example: Snowy Owls

title: Long-Distance Migration
description:
Vast seasonal movements
Example: Arctic Terns

title: Short-Distance Migration
description:
Migration within a small range
Example: Elk

title: Endogenous Rhythms
description:
Internal biological clocks for migration
Example: Circadian Rhythms

title: Zugunruhe
description:
Restlessness before migration
Example: Songbirds

title: Navigational Cues
description:
Using environmental cues to navigate
Example: Earth’s Magnetic Field

title: Orientation
description:
Maintaining direction in migration
Example: Sea Turtles

title: True Navigation
description:
Reaching a location without external cues
Example: Homing Pigeons

title: Hibernaculum
description:
Shelter for hibernating animals
Example: Snake Dens

title: Fat Reserves
description:
Stored fat for energy
Example: Bears

title: Thermoregulation
description:
Regulating body temperature
Example: Penguins

title: Daily Torpor
description:
Short-term metabolic slowdown
Example: Hummingbirds

title: Seasonal Torpor
description:
Seasonal dormancy
Example: Hedgehogs

title: Hyperphagia
description:
Excessive eating before hibernation
Example: Bears in Autumn

title: Brumation
description:
Dormancy in cold-blooded animals
Example: Snakes

title: Cryptobiosis
description:
Suspended animation in extreme conditions
Example: Tardigrades

title: Estivation
description:
Dormancy in heat
Example: Desert Frogs

title: Photoperiodism
description:
Response to seasonal daylight changes
Example: Plant Blooming

title: Homing Instinct
description:
Returning to a location instinctively
Example: Salmon

title: Dispersal
description:
Moving away to avoid inbreeding
Example: Juvenile Wolves

title: Natal Philopatry
description:
Returning to birthplace to breed
Example: Sea Turtles
